newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo '96 industry growth seen at 5.9 pct-institute.
newsitem.headline: Yugo '96 industry growth seen at 5.9 pct-institute.

text.p: The Belgrade Economics Institute has revised its earlier forecast for 1996 industrial output downward to 5.9 percent from 6.5 percent earlier, despite stronger overall performance in September.

"Industrial growth is expected to continue in the fourth quarter, but we have revised our forecast for the year since the influence of the seasonal component was slightly lower than we predicted," said Goran Pitic, an analyst with the institute.
"A realistic variant for annual output growth could be 5.9 percent," Pitic said. He was speaking after the release of the institute's latest Market Barometer report.
According to official statistics, industrial output in September rose 6.9 percent versus 2.1 percent in August and 11.3 percent against the same month in 1995.
Production rose in the non-metals, chemicals, textile, wood and energy industries, while the metallurgy and food sectors registered a drop. January-August cummulative growth was 4.8 percent.
Pitic said the structure of industry was still unfavourable with the energy and food sectors alone accounting for 30.2 and 23.9 percent in industrial output in September.

"The drop in the food industry should certainly be a warning in view of its large share in the structure of industry," Pitic said. "A change is necessary in favour of products of a higher degree of processing."
